title: Introduction to Programming
description: Master the fundamentals of programming, algorithms, and computational thinking

sets.title: Programming Fundamentals
sets.description: Core concepts and principles of programming

cards.back: Programming is the process of creating instructions for computers to follow, telling them how to perform specific tasks and solve problems using programming languages.
A programming language is a formal language with specific syntax and rules used to write instructions that computers can understand and execute, like Python, JavaScript, or Java.
An algorithm is a step-by-step procedure or set of rules used to solve a problem or accomplish a task. It's like a recipe for solving problems.
Pseudocode is a simplified, informal description of a programming algorithm that uses structural conventions of programming languages but is intended for human reading.
A variable is a named container that stores data values in a program. It can hold different types of information like numbers, text, or true/false values.
A constant is a variable whose value cannot be changed once it is assigned. It remains the same throughout the program execution.
A data type defines the kind of data a variable can hold, such as integers, floating-point numbers, strings, booleans, or more complex types.
A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task. It can take inputs (parameters) and return outputs, promoting code reusability.
A parameter is a variable in a function definition that receives a value when the function is called. It allows functions to work with different data.
A return value is the output that a function sends back to the code that called it. It's the result of the function's computation.

sets.title: Data Types & Variables
sets.description: Understanding different types of data and how to work with them

cards.back: An integer is a whole number without decimal points, such as 1, 0, -5, or 1000. It can be positive, negative, or zero.
A floating-point number is a number with decimal points, such as 3.14, -0.5, or 2.0. It can represent fractional values.
A string is a sequence of characters enclosed in quotes, such as 'Hello World' or '123'. It can contain letters, numbers, and symbols.
A boolean is a data type that can have only two values: true or false. It's used for logical operations and decision-making.
An array is a collection of elements stored in a single variable, accessible by their index position. It can hold multiple values of the same type.
Type conversion (casting) is the process of converting a value from one data type to another, such as converting a string '123' to an integer 123.
A null value represents the absence of a value or an empty state. It indicates that a variable has no meaningful value assigned.
An object is a complex data type that can hold multiple values as properties, each with a name and value. It represents real-world entities.
Scope defines where a variable can be accessed in a program. Variables have different scopes: global (accessible everywhere) or local (accessible only in specific areas).
Initialization is the process of assigning an initial value to a variable when it is first created or declared.

sets.title: Control Structures
sets.description: Understanding how to control program flow and make decisions

cards.back: A conditional statement (if/else) allows a program to make decisions and execute different code based on whether a condition is true or false.
An if statement executes a block of code only if a specified condition is true. It's the most basic form of conditional execution.
An else statement provides an alternative block of code to execute when the condition in an if statement is false.

cards.front: What is an else if statement?
cards.back: An else if statement allows checking multiple conditions in sequence, providing different code blocks for each condition.
A switch statement is a control structure that allows executing different code blocks based on the value of a variable or expression.
A loop is a programming construct that repeats a block of code multiple times until a certain condition is met.
A for loop repeats a block of code a specific number of times, typically using a counter variable to control the iteration.
A while loop repeats a block of code as long as a specified condition remains true. It checks the condition before each iteration.
A do-while loop is similar to a while loop, but it executes the code block at least once before checking the condition.
A break statement terminates the execution of a loop or switch statement, causing the program to continue with the next statement after the loop.

sets.title: Functions & Methods
sets.description: Understanding how to create and use functions effectively

cards.back: Function definition is the process of creating a function by specifying its name, parameters, and the code it will execute when called.
Function calling is the process of executing a function by using its name followed by parentheses, optionally passing arguments.
An argument is the actual value passed to a function when it is called. It corresponds to the parameter defined in the function.
A default parameter is a parameter that has a predefined value if no argument is provided when the function is called.
Function overloading allows defining multiple functions with the same name but different parameters, enabling different behaviors based on input.
Recursion is a programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem by breaking it down into smaller, similar subproblems.
A method is a function that belongs to an object or class. It can access and modify the object's data and is called using dot notation.
A callback function is a function passed as an argument to another function, which is then invoked inside the outer function to complete some action.
A pure function always returns the same output for the same input and has no side effects (doesn't modify external state).
Function scope refers to the visibility of variables within a function. Variables declared inside a function are only accessible within that function.

sets.title: Problem Solving & Algorithms
sets.description: Learning computational thinking and algorithm design

cards.back: Computational thinking is a problem-solving approach that involves breaking down complex problems into smaller, manageable parts using logical reasoning.
Decomposition is breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable parts that are easier to understand and solve individually.
Pattern recognition is identifying similarities and common elements in problems to apply known solutions and avoid reinventing solutions.
Abstraction is focusing on the important details while hiding unnecessary complexity. It involves creating simplified models of complex systems.
Algorithm design is creating step-by-step solutions to problems in a logical and systematic way, ensuring the solution is correct and efficient.
Debugging is the process of finding and fixing errors (bugs) in computer programs by systematically identifying and resolving issues.
Testing is the process of verifying that a program works correctly by running it with various inputs and checking if the outputs are as expected.
Code documentation is writing comments and explanations in code to help others (and yourself) understand what the code does and how it works.
Code readability refers to how easily code can be understood by other programmers. It involves using clear names, proper formatting, and good structure.
Version control is a system that tracks changes to code over time, allowing developers to collaborate, revert changes, and maintain code history.

quizzes.title: Programming Fundamentals Comprehensive Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of programming basics, data types, control structures, functions, and problem solving

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of programming?
options: To create instructions for computers to follow

questions.question: What is an algorithm?
options: A step-by-step procedure to solve a problem

questions.question: What is a variable in programming?
options: A named container that stores data values

questions.question: What is the difference between an integer and a floating-point number?
options: Integers have decimal points, floating-point numbers don't
Integers are whole numbers, floating-point numbers can have decimals
Integers are always positive, floating-point numbers can be negative

questions.question: What is a string?
options: A sequence of characters enclosed in quotes

questions.question: What is a boolean?
options: A data type with only true or false values

questions.question: What is an array?
options: A collection of elements stored in one variable

questions.question: What is a function?
options: A reusable block of code that performs a specific task

questions.question: What is a parameter?
options: A variable in a function that receives a value when called

questions.question: What is a conditional statement?
options: A statement that makes decisions based on conditions

questions.question: What is an if statement?
options: A conditional statement that executes code if a condition is true

questions.question: What is an else statement?
options: Code that executes when an if condition is false

questions.question: What is a loop?
options: A construct that repeats code multiple times

questions.question: What is a for loop?
options: A loop that repeats a specific number of times

questions.question: What is a while loop?
options: A loop that continues while a condition is true

questions.question: What is debugging?
options: Finding and fixing errors in programs

questions.question: What is pseudocode?
options: A simplified description of an algorithm for human reading

questions.question: What is scope?
options: Where a variable can be accessed in a program

questions.question: What is computational thinking?
options: A problem-solving approach using logical reasoning

questions.question: What is decomposition?
options: Breaking down complex problems into smaller parts

questions.question: What is pattern recognition?
options: Identifying similarities in problems to apply known solutions

questions.question: What is abstraction?
options: Focusing on important details while hiding complexity

questions.question: What is a constant?
options: A variable whose value cannot be changed

questions.question: What is type conversion?
options: Converting a value from one data type to another

questions.question: What is a method?
options: A function that belongs to an object or class

questions.question: What is code documentation?
options: Writing comments and explanations in code

questions.question: What is testing?
options: Verifying that a program works correctly

questions.question: What is version control?
options: A system that tracks changes to code over time

questions.question: What is code readability?
options: How easily code can be understood by other programmers
